column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=Turning now to the drawings, a voice prosthesis device 20 includes a body 22 of a pliable silicone.
#Text=The silicone must be rigid enough to withstand the forces placed upon it by the wall 24 of the puncture 26 through the tracheoesophageal wall 28 in which it resides.
#Text=It must also be pliable enough to permit the folding of the retention flanges 30, 32 formed on its outside surface 34 adjacent its tracheal 36 and esophageal 38 ends, respectively.
#Text=Flanges 30, 32 are responsible for positioning body 22 in the puncture 26 and reducing the likelihood of it being displaced in either the tracheal 36 or esophageal 38 direction.
#Text=Flanges 30, 32 are sufficiently flexible that they can be collapsed or folded into non-use, or insertion, orientations as illustrated by flange 30 in FIGS. 2-3 and flange 32 in FIGS. 6-7.
#Text=Flanges 30, 32 are retained in these orientations by retainer 44 which illustratively may be cut-off portions of gelatin capsules.

#Text=Once the voice prosthesis device 20 is inserted into the puncture 26, fluids such as saliva and the like, present in the tracheoesophageal wall 28 and the esophagus 38 dissolve the retainers 44 permitting the flanges 30, 32 to assume their use orientations illustrated in FIG. 1.
#Text=FIGS. 2 and 3 illustrate one method of delivery of a voice prosthesis 20 into a puncture 26.

#Text=In this method, a pediatric catheter 46 (approximately French size 4), preferably, with a Cude tip, is threaded through the tracheostoma 50, puncture 26 and upward through the pharynx 52 and out through the mouth 54 of a patient.
#Text=The voice prosthesis 20 with flange 30 captured by a retainer 44 in folded, or insertion, orientation, is then threaded onto the tip 48 of the catheter 46.
#Text=The retainer 44 is provided with a hole 53 in the tip thereof through which catheter 46 is threaded.
#Text=A knot 55 is tied in the tip 48 of the catheter 46 to capture prosthesis 20 thereon, and the catheter 46 is pulled back downward through the pharynx 52 and puncture 26.
#Text=This properly locates voice prosthesis 20 with flange 32 in its deployed, use, orientation and flange 30 still captured in its folded, non-use orientation.

#Text=However, as retainer 44 is exposed to secretions and the like in the esophagus 38 and tracheoesophageal wall 28, retainer 44 dissolves and flange 30 deploys to its use orientation, positioning prosthesis 20 in puncture 26.
#Text=Of course, catheter 46 may be removed at any time once voice prosthesis 20 is in place in the puncture, but the clinician may choose to wait to remove catheter 46 until flange 30 is deployed.
#Text=The catheter 46 is removed by threading it back up through the pharynx 52, out through the mouth 54, untying the knot 55, and then pulling the catheter 46 out through the tracheostoma 50.
#Text=Steps in two more insertion techniques are illustrated in FIGS. 4-5.
#Text=In these techniques, a retainer 144 is employed which may or may not be soluble in fluids present in the tracheoesophageal wall and the esophagus.
#Text=These methods work equally well in both cases.
#Text=In these methods, the retainer 144 is placed over flange 30 to capture it in either forward folded (FIG. 4) or rearward folded (FIG. 5) orientation.
#Text=The catheter 46 is located as in the embodiment of FIGS. 2-3 and the prosthesis 20 with retainer 144 thereon is threaded onto the catheter 46 and secured.
#Text=The prosthesis is pulled downward through the pharynx 52 and located in the puncture 26.
#Text=As illustrated in FIG. 4, the clinician then threads the catheter back up through the pharynx 52, unties the knot 55, and pulls the catheter 46 out.

#Text=Finally, the clinician inserts a forceps, tweezers or the like 57 through the tracheostoma 50, removes the retainer 144 and pulls it out, deploying the flange 30 to its broken line position illustrated in FIG. 4.
#Text=A step in another technique for deploying flange 30 is illustrated in FIG. 5.
#Text=In FIG. 5, flange 30 has been deflected rearwardly during the process of placing a retainer 44 or 144 on the leading end of prosthesis 20.

#Text=As in the embodiment illustrated in FIG. 4, the catheter 46 is located as in the embodiment of FIGS. 2-3 and the prosthesis 20 with retainer 44 or 144 thereon is threaded onto the catheter 46 and secured.
#Text=The prosthesis is then pulled downward through the pharynx 52 and into the puncture 26.

#Text=However, instead of simply locating the prosthesis 20 correctly in the puncture 26, tension is maintained on catheter 46 sufficient to deflect the esophageal side 38 of the tracheoesophageal wall 28 toward the tracheal side 36 thereof.
#Text=Then the retainer 44 is permitted to dissolve or the retainer 144 is removed as described in connection with FIG. 4, deploying flange 30 to its broken line orientation.

#Text=Then the tension on catheter 46 is released, permitting prosthesis 20 to assume its proper orientation in puncture 26 and catheter 46 is removed, for example as described in connection with FIG. 4.
